;北京呼吁华盛顿履行其作为亚太地区东道主的义务今年晚些时候举行首脑会议，并允许香港特首李家超出席。

;

;在两党美国国会议员呼吁拜登政府禁止李家超进入香港后，中国外交部周四发表讲话国家参加 11 月在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织 (APEC) 论坛活动。

;

;国会议员早些时候表示，李光耀是“受到制裁的侵犯人权者”，他出席会议将是“侮辱所有受到中国共产党和中华人民共和国及其在香港的代理人迫害的人。”

;

;但外交部发言人王文斌表示，APEC 有自己的内部规则，东道国有责任确保所有成员都能出席会议。

;

;他补充说，美国已承诺履行东道主义务，遵守 Apec 规则并帮助成员出席会议。

;

;“我们相信美国会履行义务，并确保包括中国香港在内的所有 Apec 成员都能顺利参加会议，”他说。

;

;香港于 1991 年加入 Apec，并继续参与在 1997 年香港回归中国统治后作为独立的正式成员以“中国香港”的名义参加会议。

;

;香港由行政长官代表参加该组织的经济领导人会议

;

;但在北京对香港实施国家安全法后，李是 2020 年华盛顿制裁的中国官员之一。

;

;美国声称该立法破坏了香港的自治并限制了其人民的自由和权利。

;

;美国必须“按照惯例行事”，邀请香港参加亚太经合组织：李

;

;上个月，当被问及是否会参加旧金山峰会时，李将球交给了组织者。

;

;他说华盛顿有责任“按照惯例行事”并邀请 Apec 成员.政府消息人士还表示，他们希望在 11 月之前取消限制。

;

;美国国务院发言人在 5 月份表示，该活动的邀请尚未最终敲定。

;

;刘兆佳北京半官方智库中国港澳研究会的一名顾问表示，华盛顿可以考虑向李光耀发放单次入境签证，以便他参加会议。

;

;但他说美国内部政治可能会使 Apec 峰会的处理方式复杂化，因为民主党的乔·拜登面临 2024 年的总统大选。

;

;“正在寻求连任的乔·拜登可能会被批评对中国过于软弱或香港，如果他做出太多让步，”刘解释道。

;

;香港高级官员将在 3 年内首次访问美国和英国

;

;他补充说，这次禁令是由一个两党团体发出的，而不仅仅是反对党共和党成员。

;

;“但香港或北京是否会接受一次性签证的安排是另一回事， ”最近被任命为香港政府政策专家顾问的刘说。

;

;他强调了华盛顿最近试图安排美国和中国国防部长在新加坡举行的会议——但遭到拒绝

;

;“北京只是简单地说‘不’。对中南海领导来说，这是原则问题。你不能随心所欲地制裁我，然后要求我提出暂时解除制裁与你交谈，”他说。

;

;商务及经济发展局局长邱英华上个月出席了一个亚太经合组织部长在底特律举行会议，谈到了促进该地区可持续和包容性贸易的必要性。

;中国有望准备好人工智能 (AI) 法草案随着 ChatGPT 的快速发展，随着北京率先推出针对这项技术的新法规，中国立法者将在今年内进行审查。

;

;国务院 2023 年立法计划，中国内阁，根据本周全国人民代表大会 (NPC) 常务委员会发布的一份文件，包括提交人工智能法草案在内的 50 多项措施将提交全国人民代表大会 (NPC) 常务委员会审议。

;

;常务委员会据全国人大网站称，全国人大的常设机构，中国的国家立法机关，在将一项措施付诸表决之前，“正常情况下”将对新法律草案进行三次审议。它表示，如果仍有“需要进一步研究的重大问题”，这一过程可能会延长并需要进行更多审查。

;

;除了人工智能法（其细节尚未公布）外，国务院还在努力涉及电信、互联网数据安全、无人机和对外贸易法修正案的新措施。

;

;中国政府的立法计划反映了世界各地迫切需要建立一个强大的法律基础设施，以遏制快速发展ChatGPT 等生成式 AI 服务的开发。

;

;麦肯锡咨询公司称，生成式 AI 描述了可用于创建新内容（包括音频、代码、图像、文本、模拟和视频）的算法。该领域最近的突破有可能彻底改变人们处理内容创作的方式。

;

;“生成式 AI 彻底改变了游戏规则，”欧洲竞争事务专员玛格丽特·维斯塔格 (Margrethe Vestager) 本月早些时候在欧盟 (EU) 和美国之间的第四次贸易和技术委员会会议。她表示，欧盟和美国将在未来几周内为该技术制定一份“行为准则”草案。

;

;上个月，欧洲议会的一个重要委员会批准了欧洲人工智能法案。欧盟 27 国的人工智能法有望成为事实上的全球标准。

;

;美国和欧盟为人工智能和其他新技术制定规则，但在中国威胁问题上存在分歧

;

;4 月，互联网监管机构中国国家互联网信息办公室 (CAC) 公布了一套针对类似 ChatGPT 服务的新规则草案。它将要求开发商在向公众推出服务之前通过安全评估。

;

;这些企业还应确保其产品维护中国社会主义价值观，并且不生成暗示颠覆政权、暴力或根据 CAC 的说法，色情内容或扰乱经济或社会秩序。其规则草案已于 5 月完成征求公众意见，但尚未实施。

;

;在规模较小的情况下，位于广东省南部的科技中心深圳于 9 月通过了中国首个地方政府法规，重点是促进人工智能发展

;

;该法规于 11 月生效，要求政府成立人工智能伦理委员会，负责起草安全指南并研究该技术对数据保护、就业和其他社会问题的影响。

;

;“存在风险”：OpenAI CEO 建议全球机构监督 AI

;

;中国应对最新 AI 发展的努力甚至引起了特斯拉首席执行官埃隆·马斯克最近访问中国时的关注中国。在与高级领导层会面时，马斯克表示他们“就人工智能风险以及一些监督和监管的必要性进行了一些非常富有成效的讨论”。

;

;在 OpenAI 的 ChatGPT 发布后席卷全球之后11 月，许多中国科技公司很快推出了自己的生成式人工智能产品。

;

;在线搜索服务提供商百度、电子商务巨头阿里巴巴集团、人工智能公司商汤科技和语音识别开发商科大讯飞都推出了自己的替代方案国内服务到 ChatGPT，后者在 11 月推出后风靡全球。阿里巴巴拥有南华早报。

;中国至少三个省的警方呼吁居民阻止所有来自海外的入境者如果他们在大陆以外没有经常联系，就会打电话，说这将保护他们免受电信诈骗。

;

;江苏省徐州市和连云港市的警方周末发布的在线消息建议居民采取一些方法关闭“接听海外电话”功能。

;

;“紧急提醒！请关闭来自海外的来电！”两市民警在官方微信公众号上表示。

;

;“公安局反诈骗中心提醒大家，如果不需要接境外来电，可以主动转关闭该功能以降低被骗的风险并保护您的资金！”这些帖子补充说，指的是代表中国主要民警部队的警察局。

;

;上周早些时候，东南沿海省份福建省三明市的警方也发出了同样的通知。

;< p>;山东省潍坊市警方转发了公安部关于打击电信诈骗的教学视频，作为上月底在官方微博上发布的类似反诈骗警告的一部分。

;

;然后，他们详细描述了中国三大电信运营商——中国移动、中国联通和中国电信——的客户如何停止接听来自国外的电话。去年，这三大运营商推出了一项自动阻止所有打入海外电话的服务。

;

;这一连串的公众呼吁是中国打击猖獗的网络欺诈活动的一部分，通过系统地减少移动用户接触到通信意味着当局难以监管。

;

;一项旨在应对日益严重的电信和在线欺诈的新法律于 12 月生效，赋予执法机构在海外追捕嫌疑人的权力，并强制要求电信公司执行该法律

;

;上个月末，中国多个城市的警方敦促父母从孩子的智能手机中删除加密的消息传递应用程序，以防止他们成为欺诈的“共犯”。

;

;要防范的应用程序包括本土的海鸥、诗米达和米聊猫，以及 Telegram、WhatsApp 和 Twitter 等外国应用程序，这些应用程序在中国被屏蔽，只能通过虚拟专用网络访问。< /p>;

;然而，当局打击电信诈骗的高压手段也引发质疑。

;

;2021 年 3 月在全国推出的一款反诈骗应用程序引发了公众对强制安装和数据的抱怨隐私泄露。

;

;中国排名第一的应用程序下载由警方开发，引发隐私担忧

;

;“国家反欺诈中心”应用程序由公安部开发，计算机应急响应中国最高互联网监管机构——中国互联网信息办公室下属的团队。当局表示，它旨在警告用户任何涉嫌与欺诈活动有关的电话、短信或安装的应用程序。

;

;中国应该“赢得反欺诈人民战争的新胜利”，王晓红， 5月30日，公安部部长在打击电信诈骗工作会议上对干部说。

;

;电信和网络诈骗犯罪得到有效遏制，”王说。

;

;根据公安部最新发布的数据，去年全国破获电信诈骗案件46.4万起，比2021年增长5%。

;东南亚集团东盟将在南方举行首次联合军事演习中国海，其主席印度尼西亚周四表示，最新的多边安全演习是在该地区紧张局势和不确定性加剧的情况下进行的。

;

;该决定是在由 10 个成员组成的协会的军事指挥官会议上做出的印度尼西亚的东南亚国家联盟（东盟）将在南中国海最南端的北纳土纳海举办演习。

;

;印度尼西亚军事总司令尤多·马戈诺海军上将告诉官方新闻演习将在 9 月进行，不包括任何作战行动训练。 Margono 说，这样做的目的是加强“东盟的中心地位”。

;

;多年来，东盟的团结一直受到美国和中国在南中国海上演的竞争的考验。东盟成员国越南、菲律宾、文莱和马来西亚与北京有竞争性主张，北京声称对包括印度尼西亚专属经济区 (EEZ) 部分地区在内的大片海洋拥有主权。

;

;印度尼西亚军方发言人 Julius Widjojono 说演习与“亚洲，尤其是东南亚发生灾难的高风险”有关。

;

;作为每年约 3.5 万亿美元船舶贸易的渠道，南海最近一直处于紧张状态，因为中国在距其海岸线 1,500 公里（932 英里）的地方部署了大量海岸警卫队和渔船，以加强其主权主张。

;

;中国根据其历史地图通过广阔的“九段线”宣称拥有主权，国际仲裁法院在 2016 年裁定没有法律依据。

;

;澳大利亚和越南因越南班米、啤酒和对中国的共同担忧而联系在一起

;

;东盟长期以来一直在推动等待与中国的海上行为准则完成，其几个成员最近几个月与北京发生冲突。

;

;越南批评中国在其专属经济区的几个天然气区附近部署一艘研究船，而北京被指控派遣疑似海上民兵进入印度和东盟国家海军举行演习的水域。

;

;菲律宾指责中国海警采取“危险动作”和“侵略性战术”，并计划与菲律宾举行联合巡逻。美国除了本周与日本举行的首次三边海岸警卫队演习外。

;

;中国坚称其海岸警卫队正在中国主权领土内执行常规行动。

; Thu, 08 Jun 2023 19:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong Web3 firm Animoca’s bet on non-US markets offers buffer from SEC’s labelling of Sand token as securityhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3223414/hong-kong-web3-firm-animocas-bet-non-us-markets-offers-buffer-secs-labelling-sand-token-security?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.08 18:30;
;;

;总部位于香港的区块链独角兽 Animoca Brands 表示，它正更加关注中国以外的市场美国证券交易委员会 (SEC) 在针对交易所 Binance 和 Coinbase Global 的诉讼中将该公司的 Sand 加密货币代币标记为未注册证券。

;

;Sand 是 Animoca 的元宇宙平台 The Sandbox 使用的原生加密代币，它是 SEC 明确指定为证券的十几种此类代币之一，其他代币包括 Solana、Polygon 和 Mana，后者是 Decentraland 虚拟世界中使用的代币。美国证券交易委员会的行动给任何出售这些代币的公司带来了法律风险。

;

;“Animoca Brands 并不专注于单一领域，而是在全球开展业务，”公司联合创始人兼董事长 Yat Siu 通过电子邮件表示。 “SEC 的重点是美国，因此这不会对 Animoca Brands 在广泛使用和接受沙子的更广泛市场产生影响，包括在更先进的司法管辖区，如香港和日本。”

;

;Animoca 已经Siu 补充说，由于美国最近采取了“敌视区块链”的做法，已经“开始采取措施更加重视其他市场”。

;

;Sandbox 在 metaverse 的炒作中准备迎接新的增长

;

;Coinbase 首席执行官布赖恩阿姆斯特朗曾表示，Coinbase 没有计划将美国证券交易委员会指定的代币退市，这将引发一场关于哪些类型的加密货币构成证券的法律斗争。

;

;然而，此举可能会对其他没有如此投资于出售这些代币的交易所产生寒蝉效应。美国经纪公司 Robinhood Markets 的首席法律合规和公司事务官 Dan Gallagher 本周告诉国会委员会，该公司不能简单地通过其注册经纪人列出代币，部分原因是有关“发行人披露”的规则，因为许多加密代币

;

;“我们正在积极审查 SEC 的分析，以确定针对 Robinhood 当前的加密产品采取何种行动（如果有的话）”，Gallagher 说。 /p>;

;去年 8 月，Binance.US 表示，在美国证券交易委员会在另一起诉讼中将其认定为未注册证券后，“出于谨慎考虑”，它将下架一个名为 Amp 的代币。

;< p>;SEC 的核心问题是代币是否用于筹款以及买家是否期望获得投资回报。 SEC 针对 Binance 和 Coinbase 的投诉称，Sand 据称通过 Binance.com 上的私人销售筹集了 300 万美元，持有人被引导“合理地将 Sand 视为对 [公司] 发展沙盒的努力的投资，并期望从中获利协议”。

;

;将加密资产标记为证券是 SEC 的一种策略，“支持他们针对这些交易所的执法提议”，并且对其运营商“不是特别致命”，因为尚未有来自美国证券交易委员会的判断Tanner De Witt 驻香港的合伙人 Pádraig Walsh 说，法律程序。但他指出，这些指控确实增加了美国公司的法律风险。

;

;“它确实构成了公共执法程序中的公开声明，即特定司法管辖区的监管机构认为代币可能证券，”沃尔什说。 “因此这会带来一定程度的法律风险。”

;

;由于这些案件可能需要数年时间才能做出明确的判决，因此更迫在眉睫的后果可能是加密公司继续撤离美国，因为Walsh 补充说，这被认为“太不确定了”。<​​/p>;

;The Sandbox 的联合创始人兼首席运营官 Sabastien Borget 周四告诉专注于加密货币的媒体 Decrypt，SEC 的声明不会改变该平台的业务“在日常基础”，并且该公司“不一定同意”其代币是证券的特征。

;

;

;4 月，欧洲议会批准了 EUDR，这是一项具有里程碑意义的森林砍伐法，如果发现有以下情况，将禁止进口货物与原产国森林的破坏有关。

;

;为了消除欧盟供应链中的森林砍伐，该法律将要求向欧盟销售商品的公司出示尽职调查声明和可核实的信息，以证明产品不是在 2020 年后被砍伐的土地上种植的。

;印度尼西亚是马来西亚的主要劳动力来源地，马来西亚通常雇用数万名外国工人在马来西亚采摘油棕果大型商业种植园和员工工厂，以及家庭佣工。

;

;去年，印度尼西亚曾短暂地停止允许其国民在马来西亚工作，因为对用于招募印度尼西亚家庭工人的制度存在争议。< /p>;

;马来西亚政府当时表示，印尼家政工人遭受马来西亚雇主虐待的多起案件是这是临时禁令背后的一个主要原因。

;More than 200 mourners at a Hong Kong mosque paid their respects to three girls who were allegedly murdered by their mother, before a burial at a Muslim cemetery on Thursday afternoon.

;

;The bodies of the girls – aged two, four and five – were covered in shrouds during a ceremony at the Ammar Mosque and Osman Ramju Sadick Islamic Centre in Wan Chai. Two of the bodies were draped in black and gold-coloured material, with the other in green.

;

;A dozen men carried the bodies above the crowd as mourners took part in a 20-minute prayer organised by the Muslim Council of Hong Kong, before they were sent to the Chai Wan Muslim Cemetery.

;

;Aamina Rehman, 29, faces three counts of murder for allegedly killing her daughters in their subdivided flat in Sham Shui Po on Monday. She remains at a psychiatric institution because of her unstable state of mind and missed a court appearance on Wednesday.

;

;One resident paying his respects, a man who only gave his surname as Khan, said he had grown up with the girls' father as they were part of the same tight-knit community.

;

;While the tragedy had sparked concerns over support provided to members of ethnic minority groups, Khan, who was born and raised in Hong Kong, said authorities had been very supportive. He noted help to those in need, such as single mothers, had been provided.

;

;Hong Kong mum charged with murder of daughters still in psychiatric hospital

;

;“The government can only do so much,” Khan added, saying that if the same incident had occurred in Pakistan or India, authorities would not be as helpful.

;

;He said he believed the incident erupted following a long period of struggle.

;

;“If we are able to trace it back, we might be able to find a common difficulty we all face,” he said.

;

;Khan also suggested the language barrier might be the biggest problem for his community to integrate fully into society.

;

;Since the community was relatively small, such an incident affected everyone, he said, adding: “Everyone is connected to each other one way or another.”

;

;In the last few days, authorities and community organisations have set up mental health support teams and counselling hotlines for those suffering from emotional distress because of a spate of killings.

;

;Secretary for Home and Youth Affairs Alice Mak Mei-kuen earlier said the government would endeavour to find the “hidden cases” of residents struggling with mental health problems.

;A woman from China who almost died while climbing Mount Everest has allegedly refused to pay the Sherpa guide who saved her life a US$10,000 rescue fee, prompting a backlash on mainland social media.

;

;Two other Chinese mountain climbers who helped rescue the woman found unconscious at 8,500 metres above sea level ended up paying the fee, news site cqcb.com reported.

;

;According to Chinese media reports, the 50-year-old woman from central China's Hunan province, identified by the surname Liu, was found unconscious near the peak of Mount Everest by the Sherpa guide, who was not identified in the report, as he was escorting Fan Jiangtao to the summit on the evening of May 18.

;

;Fan agreed to help save Liu and, in doing so, knowingly abandoned his dream of reaching the summit.

;

;The two men only managed to move Liu 200 metres before they reached the limit of their endurance due to the extreme conditions. Fan then went alone to seek help and encountered Xie Ruxiang, a fellow Hunan Provincial Mountain Climbing Association member. Xie agreed to help with the rescue, abandoning his plan to reach the summit.

;

;Xie claimed his Sherpa guide, the strongest climber among them, was initially reluctant to help so he offered a reward of US$10,000 and he then agreed.

;

;Sherpa guides charge a standard fee of US$8,000 to US$10,000 to help mountaineers climb up Everest by guiding them in severe weather conditions, preparing their equipment and carrying much of the gear.

;

;Nepal issued a record 478 permits for Everest during this year's March to May climbing season.

;

;The men then worked together – Xie's Sherpa guide carried Liu on his back while Xie and Fan took turns keeping her legs elevated to help increase blood flow as they descended to a base camp, where she received treatment for several days before she recovered.

;

;Liu had successfully ascended the summit and was on her way down when she experienced problems.

;

;However, when the Sherpa guide asked Xie and Fan about his promised rescue fee, Liu refused to pay the full amount, according to Fan.

;

;“Each of us paid the guide tips of US$1,800, and she said she would pay US$1,500 as tips. For the rescue fee of US$10,000, Liu said she would only pay US$4,000,” Fan claimed.

;

;“What she said angered me. I told her, 'Since that is your attitude, I don't want a cent from you. You don't need to give me any money.'”

;

;Fan said: “I've been preparing to climb Mount Everest for 40 days and spent 400,000 yuan (US$56,000) on reaching this goal. I was unwilling to give up on my plan to reach the peak. What's more, the rescue fee was paid by me. I don't know what to say. I am just wondering why she is reluctant to pay.”

;

;“Xie and I feel bad about this incident. So far, she has not even said 'thank you' to us. She is so ungrateful! We don't want to have anything to do with her from now on,” Fan further added.

;

;The story has caught national attention in mainland China, being viewed 300 million times on Weibo alone, with many denouncing Liu.

;

;“After this saga, will future climbers save or help others on Mount Everest? I think probably not. This woman has quashed the living hope of other climbers who get into trouble climbing Everest,” one commenter said.

;

;“We should send her back to the mountain slope,” another person commented.

;

;A third commenter asked: “Does she have a conscience? Is her life not worth US$10,000?”

;

;The furious public backlash prompted Xie and Fan to ask the public not to bully Liu.

;

;“Saving her is our choice, and expressing gratitude is hers. These are two separate things,” said Xie. “We are not her and don't understand what she felt. Let's just show tolerance.”

;

;Fan agreed: “We've saved her, so we hope she can continue to live well. We should stop online attacks and humiliation.”

;If you're in Beijing, Shanghai or Seoul, you're likely to have easy access to some of the highest internet speeds in the Asia-Pacific with 5G, as will those in Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore and Australia.

;

;But there remains some way to go before the rest of the region can enjoy similarly speedy web surfing, with 5G infrastructure development still lagging in nations such as Indonesia and Bangladesh, experts at the four-day Asia Tech x Singapore expo said.

;

;The 5G network provides users with high-speed mobile internet, and while inroads have been made to get 5G on every device and handset in the region, progress has been varied.

;

;“Asia should be very proud of its 5G deployment with some very rapid outreach and capacity markets. South Korea, China, and India now are very much on the roll. Australia already has 80 per cent coverage,” said Magnus Ewerbring, Swedish telecoms giant Ericsson's Asia-Pacific chief technology officer, at the expo on Wednesday.

;

;Singapore has a regulatory framework that allows innovation in 5G development but there are countries such as Indonesia that do not yet have strong roll-outs, Ewerbring said.

;

;Singapore and Thailand, for example, have strong government support and policies to roll out the 5G “spectrum” – different bands of capabilities – so there was a lot of “buzz” in these countries about 5G, said Dennis Wong, vice-president at Singtel, Singapore's biggest telecoms company.

;

;A country's regulation and government policies offer insights into its 5G roll-out, said Duncan Kenwright, managing director of global solutions at Verizons, a telecoms company based in the US. Aside from Singapore and Thailand, Japan and Australia were also in the same class.

;

;Coverage is one way to measure 5G deployment success. Other metrics include speed, regulatory support, “bands” of 5G deployed, the number of base stations and uptake by users that also depends on the availability of 5G compatible handsets, said experts.

;

;China to launch early 6G applications by 2025 ahead of 2030 commercial roll-out

;

;About 16 per cent of Asia has 5G coverage while nearly all of Asia has 4G coverage, said Jake Saunders, Asia-Pacific director at technology research firm ABI Research. But about 36 per cent are “internet offline”, meaning they have no access at all, he said.

;

;This compares with more than 50 per cent in the US, for example. Global 5G population coverage stands at around 30 per cent but this will change by 2027 when 5G subscriptions exceed 4G ones, according to research by Ericsson.

;

;Asia-Pacific is on track for 5G subscriptions to exceed 4G ones but governments should offer stronger tax subsidies and incentives, according to Saunders.

;

;Much investment and technology changes are required to successfully deploy 5G, Singtel's Wong said, but the rewards will be plentiful.

;

;But not every country in the Asia-Pacific will deploy 5G quickly as costs outweigh benefits for many emerging countries such as Bangladesh, said Ahmed Armaan Siddiqui, executive vice-president of market operations at Bangladeshi mobile network operator Robi Axiata.

;

;“Apart from infrastructure, fibre optic connectivity is actually pivotal. For a country like Bangladesh, it is sometimes very challenging to justify the return on investment,” he said.

;

;Experts agreed that, despite the hype, it remains too early to discuss rolling out 6G networks. Research can begin but investing in 6G would be costly and could take a while before it is affordable, said Jim Lim, an executive education fellow at the National University of Singapore.

;

;Can Bangladesh's garbage-strewn capital turn its excess waste into an asset?

;

;“A lot of people think that importing a new cellular technology is just about the network readiness but it's actually more than that,” Lim said.

;

;German companies in China appear to be growing more wary of being caught in the crossfire between escalating geopolitical frictions and underwhelming market prospects, casting a pall on investor confidence and leading to a more diversified business landscape.

;

;Their sentiment towards doing business in a post-Covid China is also “not as optimistic as initially hoped”, according to a recent German Chamber of Commerce in China survey that suggests more than half of its members expect the environment to remain unchanged or perhaps even worsen this year.

;

;The results, based on a flash survey of 288 German companies in mid-May, may be the latest red flag for Beijing, which has been trying to charm and appease foreign investors to help shore up the nation's economy, while also striving to stay on good terms with Europe amid tensions with the US.

;

;German carmakers Volkswagen, BMW and Daimler, and chemicals giant BASF, accounted for 34 per cent of all European direct investment in China by value from 2018-21, according to research by New York-based think tank Rhodium Group.

;

;Will a unified domestic market help tackle China's economic growth problems?

;

;More than 40 per cent of survey respondents expressed optimism about their sector's recovery by the end of the year owing to China's reopening, a 5-percentage-point increase compared with last year.

;

;However, more than a third of those polled expected that their own industrial situations would worsen – 6 percentage points higher than last year.

;

;“Geopolitics have a profound impact on companies on the ground, prompting them to drive forward localisation and diversification strategies as risk-management measures,” said Jens Hildebrand, executive director of the chamber's north China chapter.

;

;Although almost 55 per cent of the surveyed firms said they intended to increase their investments in China over the coming two years, enthusiasm for doing so has waned in the German business community. More than 70 per cent had such plans in February 2021.

;

;Geopolitical instability is a major consideration among companies when it comes to scaling back investments, while China's lacklustre market performance has also served to undermine their confidence.

;

;They continue to follow a trend seen across China's business landscape – most foreign firms are choosing to remain in China, but many are doing so while partially withdrawing, accelerating industrial shifts elsewhere or shelving investment plans.

;

;One-fifth of the surveyed German companies now have plans to shift their supply chains away from China – less than one-third that reported such plans a year ago, when citywide lockdowns set off major concerns among investors.

;

;Investors also expect Beijing to take more effective measures to invigorate the market, with many wanting to see leaders invigorate consumer confidence with subsidies.

;

;They expect the government to create a more transparent regulatory framework, more detailed policy explanations, and easier visa procedures. More than 75 per cent of German companies reported slow processing of employee business visas.

;

;Despite Beijing's attempts to lure more investors since pulling back zero-Covid restrictions, the economy is still facing internal and external headwinds, prompting Nomura last month to cut its forecast for China's 2023 gross domestic product growth to 5.5 per cent from 5.9 per cent.

;

;April's weak economic data, including manufacturing activity, consumption and youth employment, led to gloomier prospects for the Chinese economy and rattled investors.

;

;The German chamber called on Beijing to take measures to stimulate consumer confidence, provide targeted support for businesses, and remove existing business obstacles.

;

;“China's policymakers need to act now,” it said.

;

;China's receipt of foreign direct investment fell by 3.3 per cent during the January-April period, year on year.
